newsitem.title: FRANCE: Six Corsican nationalists held in Paris.
newsitem.headline: Six Corsican nationalists held in Paris.

text.p: Six Corsican nationalists suspected of a series of guerrilla attacks on the Mediterranean island have beeen placed under formal investigation and remanded in prison in Paris, judicial sources said on Saturday.
Four of them, held in a police swoop in Corsica on Monday, are suspected of planning a series of bombings between September and March, they said.
Two others were being held for alleged conspiracy and membership of a banned organisation.
The six were remanded in prison on Friday night and two other people rounded up in Monday's raids, both women, were freed on the orders of anti-terrorist judge Gilbert Thiel, the sources said.
A ninth person, whose house in southern Corsica had contained a major arms cache found by police, would be interviewed by the same judge later on Saturday.
French Interior Minister Jean-Louis Debre said on Thursday that police had made their biggest ever arms seizure following the raids against suspected separatist guerrillas.
He told French radio nine people were initially being held on the island in Ajaccio and some had admitted responsibility in six bombings over the past six months.
The bombings were claimed by the hardline historic wing of the separatist Corsican National Liberation Front, which seeks greater autonomy from Paris.
The ministry said police had seized pistols, revolvers, sawn-off shotguns, a shrapnel hand grenade, explosives and gas containers connected to detonators.

As a result of the round-up, police also uncovered on Thursday another arms cache in an isolated farm building including a rocket launcher, an assault rifle, four sub-machine guns, explosives, communications equipment and hoods, the trademark headgear of separatist guerrillas.

FLNC separatists have claimed hundreds of bombings in a campaign spanning two decades. Recent targets have included tax and post offices, bank branches and offices of state-run companies France-Telecom and Air France.
